newsitem.title: UK: Italy will be offered delayed EMU entry-Fin Times.
newsitem.headline: Italy will be offered delayed EMU entry-Fin Times.

text.p: Italy will be offered a deal that would delay its entry into European Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) until 2000 or 2001, the Financial Times said on Wednesday.
The newspaper, quoting unnamed senior monetary officials, described the deal as a "face-saving compromise designed by senior European central bankers and monetary officials".

The plan, which could be extended to Spain and Portugal, would meet German fears that the launch of a strong and stable single European currency, or euro, in 1999 could be compromised if Italy was among the first EMU members, the Financial Times said.

Central bank and finance ministry officials have begun to work on a package to assuage German fears, while offering Italy the certainty it could join the EMU within 12 to 18 months of the launch of the euro. An Italian entry in 2000 and 2001 would still be ahead of the actual introduction of euro notes and coins in 2002.

"The trick is to allow the Germans to say that Italy is out of the first wave...while making the Italians feel comfortable enough to say that they are more or less in," the Financial Times quoted a senior monetary official as saying.
The newspaper's report followed comments by Spanish Foreign Minister Abel Matutes on Tuesday that Spain and Italy were on course to join EMU from the start on January 1, 1999.
